ruleset.name: pmd-rules
ruleset.description: IHG PMD Plugin preferences rule set

rule.message: All methods are static. Consider using Singleton instead. Alternatively, you could add a private constructor or make the class abstract to silence this warning.
rule.name: UseSingleton
rule.description: If you have a class that has nothing but static methods, consider making it a Singleton. Note that this doesn't apply to abstract classes, since their subclasses may well include non-static methods. Also, if you want this class to be a Singleton, remember to add a private constructor to prevent instantiation.

rule.message: Avoid unnecessary if..then..else statements when returning a boolean
rule.name: SimplifyBooleanReturns
rule.description: Avoid unnecessary if..then..else statements when returning a boolean

rule.message: Avoid unnecessary comparisons in boolean expressions
rule.name: SimplifyBooleanExpressions
rule.description: Avoid unnecessary comparisons in boolean expressions - this makes simple code seem complicated.

rule.message: Switch statements should have a default label
rule.name: SwitchStmtsShouldHaveDefault
rule.description: Switch statements should have a default label.

rule.message: Deeply nested if..then statements are hard to read
rule.name: AvoidDeeplyNestedIfStmts
rule.description: Deeply nested if..then statements are hard to read.

rule.message: Avoid reassigning parameters such as ''{0}''
rule.name: AvoidReassigningParameters
rule.description: Reassigning values to parameters is a questionable practice. Use a temporary local variable instead.

rule.message: A high ratio of statements to labels in a switch statement. Consider refactoring.
rule.name: SwitchDensity
rule.description: A high ratio of statements to labels in a switch statement implies that the switch statement is doing too much work. Consider moving the statements either into new methods, or creating subclasses based on the switch variable.

rule.message: Overridable {0} called during object construction
rule.name: ConstructorCallsOverridableMethod
rule.description: Calling overridable methods during construction poses a risk of invoking methods on an incompletely constructed object. This situation can be difficult to discern. It may leave the sub-class unable to construct its superclass or forced to replicate the construction process completely within itself, losing the ability to call super(). If the default constructor contains a call to an overridable method, the subclass may be completely uninstantiable. Note that this includes method calls throughout the control flow graph - i.e., if a constructor Foo() calls a private method bar() that calls a public method buz(), there's a problem.

rule.message: Avoid instantiation through private constructors from outside of the constructor's class.
rule.name: AccessorClassGeneration
rule.description: Instantiation by way of private constructors from outside of the constructor's class often causes the generation of an accessor. A factory method, or non-privitization of the constructor can eliminate this situation. The generated class file is actually an interface. It gives the accessing class the ability to invoke a new hidden package scope constructor that takes the interface as a supplementary parameter. This turns a private constructor effectively into one with package scope, though not visible to the naked eye.

rule.message: This final field could be made static
rule.name: FinalFieldCouldBeStatic
rule.description: If a final field is assigned to a compile-time constant, it could be made static, thus saving overhead in each object

rule.message: Ensure that resources like this {0} object are closed after use
rule.name: CloseResource
rule.description: Ensure that resources (like Connection, Statement, and ResultSet objects) are always closed after use

rule.message: Non-static initializers are confusing
rule.name: NonStaticInitializer
rule.description: A nonstatic initializer block will be called any time a constructor is invoked (just prior to invoking the constructor). While this is a valid language construct, it is rarely used and is confusing.

rule.message: The default label should be the last label in a switch statement
rule.name: DefaultLabelNotLastInSwitchStmt
rule.description: By convention, the default label should be the last label in a switch statement.

rule.message: A non-case label was present in a switch statement
rule.name: NonCaseLabelInSwitchStatement
rule.description: A non-case label (e.g. a named break/continue label) was present in a switch statement. This legal, but confusing. It is easy to mix up the case labels and the non-case labels.

rule.message: This call to Collection.toArray() may be optimizable
rule.name: OptimizableToArrayCall
rule.description: A call to Collection.toArray can use the Collection's size vs an empty Array of the desired type.

rule.message: Avoid equality comparisons with Double.NaN
rule.name: BadComparison
rule.description: Avoid equality comparisons with Double.NaN - these are likely to be logic errors.

rule.message: Avoid using equals() to compare against null
rule.name: EqualsNull
rule.description: Newbie programmers sometimes get the comparison concepts confused and use equals() to compare to null.

rule.message: Avoid instantiating an object just to call getClass() on it; use the .class public member instead
rule.name: InstantiationToGetClass
rule.description: Avoid instantiating an object just to call getClass() on it; use the .class public member instead

rule.message: Avoid idempotent operations (like assigning a variable to itself)
rule.name: IdempotentOperations
rule.description: Avoid idempotent operations - they are silly.

rule.message: When instantiating a SimpleDateFormat object, specify a Locale
rule.name: SimpleDateFormatNeedsLocale
rule.description: Be sure to specify a Locale when creating a new instance of SimpleDateFormat.

rule.message: Private field ''{0}'' could be made final; it is only initialized in the declaration or constructor.
rule.name: ImmutableField
rule.description: Identifies private fields whose values never change once they are initialized either in the declaration of the field or by a constructor. This aids in converting existing classes to immutable classes.

rule.message: When doing a String.toLowerCase()/toUpperCase() call, use a Locale
rule.name: UseLocaleWithCaseConversions
rule.description: When doing a String.toLowerCase()/toUpperCase() call, use a Locale. This avoids problems with certain locales, i.e. Turkish.

rule.message: Avoid protected fields in a final class. Change to private or package access.
rule.name: AvoidProtectedFieldInFinalClass
rule.description: Do not use protected fields in final classes since they cannot be subclassed. Clarify your intent by using private or package access modifiers instead.

rule.message: Possible unsafe assignment to a non-final static field in a constructor.
rule.name: AssignmentToNonFinalStatic
rule.description: Identifies a possible unsafe usage of a static field.

rule.message: Class cannot be instantiated and does not provide any static methods or fields
rule.name: MissingStaticMethodInNonInstantiatableClass
rule.description: A class that has private constructors and does not have any static methods or fields cannot be used.

rule.message: Use block level rather than method level synchronization
rule.name: AvoidSynchronizedAtMethodLevel
rule.description: Method level synchronization can backfire when new code is added to the method. Block-level synchronization helps to ensure that only the code that needs synchronization gets it.

rule.message: A switch statement does not contain a break
rule.name: MissingBreakInSwitch
rule.description: A switch statement without an enclosed break statement may be a bug.

rule.message: Call Thread.notifyAll() rather than Thread.notify()
rule.name: UseNotifyAllInsteadOfNotify
rule.description: Thread.notify() awakens a thread monitoring the object. If more than one thread is monitoring, then only one is chosen. The thread chosen is arbitrary; thus it's usually safer to call notifyAll() instead.

property.name: xpath

rule.message: An instanceof check is being performed on the caught exception. Create a separate catch clause for this exception type.
rule.name: AvoidInstanceofChecksInCatchClause
rule.description: Each caught exception type should be handled in its own catch clause.

rule.message: This abstract class does not have any abstract methods
rule.name: AbstractClassWithoutAbstractMethod
rule.description: The abstract class does not contain any abstract methods. An abstract class suggests an incomplete implementation, which is to be completed by subclasses implementing the abstract methods. If the class is intended to be used as a base class only (not to be instantiated direcly) a protected constructor can be provided prevent direct instantiation.

rule.message: No need to check for null before an instanceof
rule.name: SimplifyConditional
rule.description: No need to check for null before an instanceof; the instanceof keyword returns false when given a null argument.

rule.message: Use equals() to compare object references.
rule.name: CompareObjectsWithEquals
rule.description: Use equals() to compare object references; avoid comparing them with ==.

rule.message: Position literals first in String comparisons
rule.name: PositionLiteralsFirstInComparisons
rule.description: Position literals first in String comparisons - that way if the String is null you won't get a NullPointerException, it'll just return false.

rule.message: Consider simply returning the value vs storing it in local variable ''{0}''
rule.name: UnnecessaryLocalBeforeReturn
rule.description: Avoid unnecessarily creating local variables

rule.message: Singleton is not thread safe
rule.name: NonThreadSafeSingleton
rule.description:
Non-thread safe singletons can result in bad state changes. If possible, get rid of static singletons by directly instantiating the object. Static singletons are usually not needed as only a single instance exists anyway. Other possible fixes are to synchronize the entire method or to use an initialize-on-demand holder class (do not use the double-check idiom).
See Effective Java, item 48.

rule.message: Document empty method
rule.name: UncommentedEmptyMethod
rule.description: Uncommented Empty Method finds instances where a method does not contain statements, but there is no comment. By explicitly commenting empty methods it is easier to distinguish between intentional (commented) and unintentional empty methods.
rule.example: public void doSomething() { }

rule.message: An Interface should be used only to model a behaviour; consider converting this to a class.
rule.name: AvoidConstantsInterface
rule.description: An interface should be used only to model a behaviour of a class: using an interface as a container of constants is a poor usage pattern.

rule.message: Static DateFormatter objects should be accessed in a synchronized manner
rule.name: UnsynchronizedStaticDateFormatter
rule.description: SimpleDateFormat is not synchronized. Sun recomends separate format instances for each thread. If multiple threads must access a static formatter, the formatter must be synchronized either on method or block level.

rule.message: Caught exception is rethrown, original stack trace may be lost
rule.name: PreserveStackTrace
rule.description: Throwing a new exception from a catch block without passing the original exception into the new Exception will cause the true stack trace to be lost, and can cause problems debugging problems

rule.message: Local variable could be declared final
rule.name: LocalVariableCouldBeFinal
rule.description: A local variable assigned only once can be declared final.

rule.message: Parameter ''{0}'' is not assigned and could be declared final
rule.name: MethodArgumentCouldBeFinal
rule.description: A method argument that is never assigned can be declared final.

rule.message: Avoid instantiating new objects inside loops
rule.name: AvoidInstantiatingObjectsInLoops
rule.description: Detects when a new object is created inside a loop

rule.message: Use ArrayList instead of Vector
rule.name: UseArrayListInsteadOfVector
rule.description: ArrayList is a much better Collection implementation than Vector.

rule.message: This call to String.startsWith can be rewritten using String.charAt(0)
rule.name: SimplifyStartsWith
rule.description: Since it passes in a literal of length 1, this call to String.startsWith can be rewritten using String.charAt(0) to save some time.

rule.message: Prefer StringBuffer over += for concatenating strings
rule.name: UseStringBufferForStringAppends
rule.description: Finds usages of += for appending strings.

rule.message: Use asList instead of tight loops
rule.name: UseArraysAsList
rule.description: The class java.util.Arrays has a "asList" method that should be use when you want to create a new List from an array of objects. It is faster than executing a loop to cpy all the elements of the array one by one

rule.message: System.arrayCopy is more efficient
rule.name: AvoidArrayLoops
rule.description: Instead of copying data between two arrays, use System.arrayCopy method

rule.message: Unnecessary wrapper object creation
rule.name: UnnecessaryWrapperObjectCreation
rule.description: Parsing method should be called directy instead.

rule.message: A method/constructor shouldn't explicitly throw java.lang.Exception
rule.name: SignatureDeclareThrowsException
rule.description: It is unclear which exceptions that can be thrown from the methods. It might be difficult to document and understand the vague interfaces. Use either a class derived from RuntimeException or a checked exception.
rule.example: public void methodThrowingException() throws Exception { }

rule.message: Avoid using exceptions as flow control
rule.name: ExceptionAsFlowControl
rule.description: Using Exceptions as flow control leads to GOTOish code.

rule.message: Avoid catching NullPointerException; consider removing the cause of the NPE.
rule.name: AvoidCatchingNPE
rule.description: Code should never throw NPE under normal circumstances. A catch block may hide the original error, causing other more subtle errors in its wake.

rule.message: Avoid throwing raw exception types
rule.name: AvoidThrowingRawExceptionTypes
rule.description: Avoid throwing certain exception types. Rather than throw a raw RuntimeException, Throwable, Exception, or Error, use a subclassed exception or error instead.

rule.message: Avoid throwing null pointer exceptions
rule.name: AvoidThrowingNullPointerException
rule.description: Avoid throwing a NullPointerException - it's confusing because most people will assume that the virtual machine threw it. Consider using an IllegalArgumentException instead; this will be clearly seen as a programmer initiated exception.

rule.message: A catch statement that catches an exception only to rethrow it should be avoided
rule.name: AvoidRethrowingException
rule.description: Catch blocks that merely rethrow a caught exception only add to code size and runtime complexity.

rule.message: In J2EE, getClassLoader() might not work as expected. Use Thread.currentThread().getContextClassLoader() instead.
rule.name: UseProperClassLoader
rule.description: In J2EE getClassLoader() might not work as expected. Use Thread.currentThread().getContextClassLoader() instead.

rule.message: Avoid unused private fields such as ''{0}''
rule.name: UnusedPrivateField
rule.description: Detects when a private field is declared and/or assigned a value, but not used.

rule.message: Avoid unused local variables such as ''{0}''
rule.name: UnusedLocalVariable
rule.description: Detects when a local variable is declared and/or assigned, but not used.

rule.message: Avoid unused private methods such as ''{0}''
rule.name: UnusedPrivateMethod
rule.description: Unused Private Method detects when a private method is declared but is unused.

rule.message: Avoid unused {0} parameters such as ''{1}''
rule.name: UnusedFormalParameter
rule.description: Avoid passing parameters to methods or constructors and then not using those parameters.

rule.message: Consider replacing this Vector with the newer java.util.List
rule.name: ReplaceVectorWithList
rule.description: Consider replacing this Vector with the newer java.util.List

rule.message: Consider replacing this Hashtable with the newer java.util.Map
rule.name: ReplaceHashtableWithMap
rule.description: Consider replacing this Hashtable with the newer java.util.Map

rule.message: Consider replacing this Enumeration with the newer java.util.Iterator
rule.name: ReplaceEnumerationWithIterator
rule.description: Consider replacing this Enumeration with the newer java.util.Iterator

rule.message: Avoid using enum as an identifier; it's a reserved word in JDK 1.5
rule.name: AvoidEnumAsIdentifier
rule.description: Finds all places 'enum' is used as an identifier is used

rule.message: Avoid using assert as an identifier; it's a reserved word in JDK 1.4
rule.name: AvoidAssertAsIdentifier
rule.description: Finds all places 'assert' is used as an identifier is used

rule.message: Avoid instantiating Integer objects. Call Integer.valueOf() instead
rule.name: IntegerInstantiation
rule.description: In JDK 1.5, calling new Integer() causes memory allocation. Integer.valueOf() is more memory friendly.

rule.message: Avoid using if statements without curly braces
rule.name: IfStmtsMustUseBraces
rule.description: Avoid using if statements without using curly braces

rule.message: Avoid using 'while' statements without curly braces
rule.name: WhileLoopsMustUseBraces
rule.description: Avoid using 'while' statements without using curly braces

rule.message: Avoid using 'if...else' statements without curly braces
rule.name: IfElseStmtsMustUseBraces
rule.description: Avoid using if..else statements without using curly braces

rule.message: Avoid using 'for' statements without curly braces
rule.name: ForLoopsMustUseBraces
rule.description: Avoid using 'for' statements without using curly braces

rule.message: Avoid empty finalize methods
rule.name: EmptyFinalizer
rule.description: If the finalize() method is empty, then it does not need to exist.

rule.message: Finalize should do something besides just calling super.finalize()
rule.name: FinalizeOnlyCallsSuperFinalize
rule.description: If the finalize() is implemented, it should do something besides just calling super.finalize().

rule.message: Finalize methods should not be overloaded
rule.name: FinalizeOverloaded
rule.description: Methods named finalize() should not have parameters. It is confusing and probably a bug to overload finalize(). It will not be called by the VM.

rule.message: Last statement in finalize method should be a call to super.finalize()
rule.name: FinalizeDoesNotCallSuperFinalize
rule.description: If the finalize() is implemented, its last action should be to call super.finalize

rule.message: If you override finalize(), make it protected
rule.name: FinalizeShouldBeProtected
rule.description: If you override finalize(), make it protected. If you make it public, other classes may call it.

rule.message: Avoid calling finalize() explicitly
rule.name: AvoidCallingFinalize
rule.description: Object.finalize() is called by the garbage collector on an object when garbage collection determines that there are no more references to the object.

rule.message: You have a suite() method that is not both public and static, so JUnit won't call it to get your TestSuite. Is that what you wanted to do?
rule.name: JUnitStaticSuite
rule.description: The suite() method in a JUnit test needs to be both public and static.

rule.message: You may have misspelled a JUnit framework method (setUp or tearDown)
rule.name: JUnitSpelling
rule.description: Some JUnit framework methods are easy to misspell.

rule.message: JUnit assertions should include a message
rule.name: JUnitAssertionsShouldIncludeMessage
rule.description: JUnit assertions should include a message - i.e., use the three argument version of assertEquals(), not the two argument version.

rule.message: JUnit tests should include assert() or fail()
rule.name: JUnitTestsShouldIncludeAssert
rule.description: JUnit tests should include at least one assertion. This makes the tests more robust, and using assert with messages provide the developer a clearer idea of what the test does.

rule.message: This class name ends with 'Test' but contains no test cases
rule.name: TestClassWithoutTestCases
rule.description: Test classes end with the suffix Test. Having a non-test class with that name is not a good practice, since most people will assume it is a test case. Test classes have test methods named testXXX.

rule.message: assertTrue(true) or similar statements are unnecessary
rule.name: UnnecessaryBooleanAssertion
rule.description: A JUnit test assertion with a boolean literal is unnecessary since it always will eval to the same thing. Consider using flow control (in case of assertTrue(false) or similar) or simply removing statements like assertTrue(true) and assertFalse(false). If you just want a test to halt, use the fail method.

rule.message: Use assertEquals(x, y) instead of assertTrue(x.equals(y))
rule.name: UseAssertEqualsInsteadOfAssertTrue
rule.description: This rule detects JUnit assertions in object equality. These assertions should be made by more specific methods, like assertEquals.

rule.message: Use assertSame(x, y) instead of assertTrue(x==y), or assertNotSame(x,y) vs assertFalse(x==y)
rule.name: UseAssertSameInsteadOfAssertTrue
rule.description: This rule detects JUnit assertions in object references equality. These assertions should be made by more specific methods, like assertSame, assertNotSame.

rule.message: Use assertNull(x) instead of assertTrue(x==null), or assertNotNull(x) vs assertFalse(x==null)
rule.name: UseAssertNullInsteadOfAssertTrue
rule.description: This rule detects JUnit assertions in object references equality. These assertions should be made by more specific methods, like assertNull, assertNotNull.

rule.message: assertTrue(!expr) can be replaced by assertFalse(expr)
rule.name: SimplifyBooleanAssertion

rule.message: Use the correct logging statement for logging exceptions
rule.name: UseCorrectExceptionLogging
rule.description: To make sure the full stacktrace is printed out, use the logging statement with 2 arguments: a String and a Throwable.

rule.message: Logger should be defined private static final and have the correct class
rule.name: ProperLogger
rule.description: Logger should normally be defined private static final and have the correct class. Private final Log log; is also allowed for rare cases when loggers need to be passed around, but the logger needs to be passed into the constructor.

rule.message: Object clone() should be implemented with super.clone()
rule.name: ProperCloneImplementation
rule.description: Object clone() should be implemented with super.clone()

rule.message: clone() method should throw CloneNotSupportedException
rule.name: CloneThrowsCloneNotSupportedException
rule.description: The method clone() should throw a CloneNotSupportedException

rule.message: clone() method should be implemented only if implementing Cloneable interface
rule.name: CloneMethodMustImplementCloneable
rule.description: The method clone() should only be implemented if the class implements the Cloneable interface with the exception of a final method that only throws CloneNotSupportedException

rule.message: Classes implementing Serializable should set a serialVersionUID
rule.name: MissingSerialVersionUID
rule.description: Classes that are serializable should provide a serialVersionUID field.

rule.message: Class contains more than one Logger
rule.name: MoreThanOneLogger
rule.description: Normally only one logger is used in each class.

rule.message: The Logger variable declaration does not contain the static and final modifiers
rule.name: LoggerIsNotStaticFinal
rule.description: In most cases, the Logger can be declared static and final.

rule.message: System.out.print is used
rule.name: SystemPrintln
rule.description: System.(out|err).print is used, consider using a logger.

rule.message: Avoid printStackTrace(); use a logger call instead.
rule.name: AvoidPrintStackTrace
rule.description: Avoid printStackTrace(); use a logger call instead.

rule.message: Returning ''{0}'' may expose an internal array
rule.name: MethodReturnsInternalArray
rule.description: Exposing internal arrays directly allows the user to modify some code that could be critical. It is safer to return a copy of the array.

rule.message: The user-supplied array ''{0}'' is stored directly
rule.name: ArrayIsStoredDirectly
rule.description: Constructors and methods receiving arrays should clone objects and store the copy. This prevents that future changes from the user affect the internal functionality.

rule.message: Avoid variables with short names like {0}
rule.name: ShortVariable
rule.description: Detects when a field, local or parameter has a short name.

rule.message: Avoid using short method names
rule.name: ShortMethodName
rule.description: Detects when very short method names are used.

rule.message: {0} variable {1} should begin with {2}
rule.name: VariableNamingConventions
rule.description: A variable naming conventions rule - customize this to your liking. Currently, it checks that final variables should be all caps and non-final variables should not include underscores.

rule.message: Method name does not begin with a lower case character.
rule.name: MethodNamingConventions
rule.description: Method names should always begin with a lower case character, and should not contain underscores.

rule.message: Class names should begin with an uppercase character
rule.name: ClassNamingConventions
rule.description: Class names should always begin with an upper case character.
rule.example: public class Foo {}

rule.message: Abstract classes should be named 'AbstractXXX'
rule.name: AbstractNaming
rule.description: Abstract classes should be named 'AbstractXXX'.
rule.example: public abstract class Foo { // should be AbstractFoo }

rule.message: Avoid using dollar signs in variable/method/class/interface names
rule.name: AvoidDollarSigns
rule.description: Avoid using dollar signs in variable/method/class/interface names.
rule.example: public class Fo$o { // yikes! }

rule.message: Classes should not have non-constructor methods with the same name as the class
rule.name: MethodWithSameNameAsEnclosingClass
rule.description: Non-constructor methods should not have the same name as the enclosing class.

rule.message: The method name and return type are suspiciously close to hashCode()
rule.name: SuspiciousHashcodeMethodName
rule.description: The method name and return type are suspiciously close to hashCode(), which may mean you are intending to override the hashCode() method.

rule.message: The field name indicates a constant but its modifiers do not
rule.name: SuspiciousConstantFieldName
rule.description: A field name is all in uppercase characters, which in Sun's Java naming conventions indicate a constant. However, the field is not final.

rule.message: The method name and parameter number are suspiciously close to equals(Object)
rule.name: SuspiciousEqualsMethodName
rule.description: The method name and parameter number are suspiciously close to equals(Object), which may mean you are intending to override the equals(Object) method.

property.name: xpath

rule.message: It is somewhat confusing to have a field name matching the declaring class name
rule.name: AvoidFieldNameMatchingTypeName
rule.description: It is somewhat confusing to have a field name matching the declaring class name. This proabably means that type and or field names could be more precise.

rule.message: It is somewhat confusing to have a field name with the same name as a method
rule.name: AvoidFieldNameMatchingMethodName
rule.description: It is somewhat confusing to have a field name with the same name as a method. While this is totally legal, having information (field) and actions (method) is not clear naming.

rule.message: Method {0} is not a constructor but it can be confused with one
rule.name: AvoidNonConstructorMethodsWithClassName
rule.description: It is very easy to confuse methods with classname with constructors. It is preferrable to name these non-constructor methods in a different way.

rule.message: All classes and interfaces must belong to a named package
rule.name: NoPackage
rule.description: Detects when a class or interface does not have a package definition.

rule.message: Avoid naming non-fields with the prefix 'm_'
rule.name: MisleadingVariableName
rule.description: Detects when a non-field has a name starting with 'm_'. This usually indicates a field and thus is confusing.

rule.message: Avoid empty catch blocks
rule.name: EmptyCatchBlock
rule.description: Empty Catch Block finds instances where an exception is caught, but nothing is done. In most circumstances, this swallows an exception which should either be acted on or reported.

rule.message: Avoid empty 'if' statements
rule.name: EmptyIfStmt
rule.description: Empty If Statement finds instances where a condition is checked but nothing is done about it.

rule.message: Avoid empty 'while' statements
rule.name: EmptyWhileStmt
rule.description: Empty While Statement finds all instances where a while statement does nothing. If it is a timing loop, then you should use Thread.sleep() for it; if it's a while loop that does a lot in the exit expression, rewrite it to make it clearer.

rule.message: Avoid empty try blocks
rule.name: EmptyTryBlock
rule.description: Avoid empty try blocks - what's the point?

rule.message: Avoid empty finally blocks
rule.name: EmptyFinallyBlock
rule.description: Avoid empty finally blocks - these can be deleted.

rule.message: Avoid empty switch statements
rule.name: EmptySwitchStatements
rule.description: Avoid empty switch statements.

rule.message: Avoid modifying an outer loop incrementer in an inner loop for update expression
rule.name: JumbledIncrementer
rule.description: Avoid jumbled loop incrementers - it's usually a mistake, and it's confusing even if it's what's intended.

rule.message: This for loop could be simplified to a while loop
rule.name: ForLoopShouldBeWhileLoop
rule.description: Some for loops can be simplified to while loops - this makes them more concise.

rule.message: Avoid unnecessary temporaries when converting primitives to Strings
rule.name: UnnecessaryConversionTemporary
rule.description: Avoid unnecessary temporaries when converting primitives to Strings

rule.message: Ensure you override both equals() and hashCode()
rule.name: OverrideBothEqualsAndHashcode
rule.description: Override both public boolean Object.equals(Object other), and public int Object.hashCode(), or override neither. Even if you are inheriting a hashCode() from a parent class, consider implementing hashCode and explicitly delegating to your superclass.

rule.message: Double checked locking is not thread safe in Java.
rule.name: DoubleCheckedLocking
rule.description: Partially created objects can be returned by the Double Checked Locking pattern when used in Java. An optimizing JRE may assign a reference to the baz variable before it creates the object the reference is intended to point to. For more details see http://www.javaworld.com/javaworld/jw-02-2001/jw-0209-double.html.

rule.message: Avoid returning from a finally block
rule.name: ReturnFromFinallyBlock
rule.description: Avoid returning from a finally block - this can discard exceptions.

rule.message: Avoid empty synchronized blocks
rule.name: EmptySynchronizedBlock
rule.description: Avoid empty synchronized blocks - they're useless.

rule.message: Avoid unnecessary return statements
rule.name: UnnecessaryReturn
rule.description: Avoid unnecessary return statements

rule.message: Empty static initializer was found
rule.name: EmptyStaticInitializer
rule.description: An empty static initializer was found.

rule.message: Do not use 'if' statements that are always true or always false
rule.name: UnconditionalIfStatement
rule.description: Do not use "if" statements that are always true or always false.

rule.message: An empty statement (semicolon) not part of a loop
rule.name: EmptyStatementNotInLoop
rule.description: An empty statement (aka a semicolon by itself) that is not used as the sole body of a for loop or while loop is probably a bug. It could also be a double semicolon, which is useless and should be removed.

rule.message: Avoid instantiating Boolean objects; reference Boolean.TRUE or Boolean.FALSE or call Boolean.valueOf() instead.
rule.name: BooleanInstantiation
rule.description: Avoid instantiating Boolean objects; you can reference Boolean.TRUE, Boolean.FALSE, or call Boolean.valueOf() instead.

property.name: xpath

rule.message: Unnecessary final modifier in final class
rule.name: UnnecessaryFinalModifier
rule.description: When a class has the final modifier, all the methods are automatically final.

rule.message: These nested if statements could be combined
rule.name: CollapsibleIfStatements
rule.description: Sometimes two 'if' statements can be consolidated by separating their conditions with a boolean short-circuit operator.

rule.message: Overriding method merely calls super
rule.name: UselessOverridingMethod
rule.description: The overriding method merely calls the same method defined in a superclass

rule.message: This usage of the Collection.toArray() method will throw a ClassCastException.
rule.name: ClassCastExceptionWithToArray
rule.description: if you need to get an array of a class from your Collection, you should pass an array of the desidered class as the parameter of the toArray method. Otherwise you will get a ClassCastException.

rule.message: Avoid creating BigDecimal with a decimal (float/double) literal. Use a String literal
rule.name: AvoidDecimalLiteralsInBigDecimalConstructor
rule.description:
One might assume that "new BigDecimal(.1)" is exactly equal to .1, but it is actually equal to .1000000000000000055511151231257827021181583404541015625. This is so because .1 cannot be represented exactly as a double (or, for that matter, as a binary fraction of any finite length). Thus, the long value that is being passed in to the constructor is not exactly equal to .1, appearances notwithstanding.
The (String) constructor, on the other hand, is perfectly predictable: 'new BigDecimal(".1")' is exactly equal to .1, as one would expect. Therefore, it is generally recommended that the (String) constructor be used in preference to this one.

rule.message: An operation on an Immutable object (BigDecimal or BigInteger) won''t change the object itself
rule.name: UselessOperationOnImmutable
rule.description: An operation on an Immutable object (BigDecimal or BigInteger) won't change the object itself. The result of the operation is a new object. Therefore, ignoring the operation result is an error.

rule.message: The null check here is misplaced; if the variable is null there'll be a NullPointerException
rule.name: MisplacedNullCheck
rule.description: The null check here is misplaced. if the variable is null you'll get a NullPointerException. Either the check is useless (the variable will never be "null") or it's incorrect.

rule.message: Invoke equals() on the object you''ve already ensured is not null
rule.name: UnusedNullCheckInEquals
rule.description: After checking an object reference for null, you should invoke equals() on that object rather than passing it to another object's equals() method.

rule.message: Avoid using ThreadGroup; it is not thread safe
rule.name: AvoidThreadGroup
rule.description: Avoid using ThreadGroup; although it is intended to be used in a threaded environment it contains methods that are not thread safe.

rule.message: Method call on object which may be null
rule.name: BrokenNullCheck
rule.description: The null check is broken since it will throw a Nullpointer itself. The reason is that a method is called on the object when it is null. It is likely that you used || instead of && or vice versa.

rule.message: Avoid duplicate imports such as ''{0}''
rule.name: DuplicateImports
rule.description: Avoid duplicate import statements.

rule.message: Avoid importing anything from the package 'java.lang'
rule.name: DontImportJavaLang
rule.description: Avoid importing anything from the package 'java.lang'. These classes are automatically imported (JLS 7.5.3).

rule.message: Avoid unused imports such as ''{0}''
rule.name: UnusedImports
rule.description: Avoid unused import statements.

rule.message: No need to import a type that's in the same package
rule.name: ImportFromSamePackage
rule.description: No need to import a type that's in the same package.

rule.message: The String literal {0} appears {1} times in this file; the first occurrence is on line {2}
rule.name: AvoidDuplicateLiterals
rule.description: Code containing duplicate String literals can usually be improved by declaring the String as a constant field.

rule.message: Avoid instantiating String objects; this is usually unnecessary.
rule.name: StringInstantiation
rule.description: Avoid instantiating String objects; this is usually unnecessary.

rule.message: Avoid calling toString() on String objects; this is unnecessary
rule.name: StringToString
rule.description: Avoid calling toString() on String objects; this is unnecessary

rule.message: Avoid concatenating nonliterals in a StringBuffer constructor or append()
rule.name: InefficientStringBuffering
rule.description: Avoid concatenating non literals in a StringBuffer constructor or append().

rule.message: Using equalsIgnoreCase() is cleaner than using toUpperCase/toLowerCase().equals()
rule.name: UnnecessaryCaseChange
rule.description: Using equalsIgnoreCase() is faster than using toUpperCase/toLowerCase().equals()

rule.message: This is an inefficient use of StringBuffer.toString; just call StringBuffer.length instead
rule.name: UseStringBufferLength
rule.description: Use StringBuffer.length() to determine StringBuffer length rather than using StringBuffer.toString().equals("") or StringBuffer.toString().length() ==

rule.message: Avoid appending characters as strings in StringBuffer.append
rule.name: AppendCharacterWithChar
rule.description: Avoid concatenating characters as strings in StringBuffer.append

rule.message: StringBuffer.append is called {0} consecutive times with literal Strings. Use a single append with a single String.
rule.name: ConsecutiveLiteralAppends
rule.description: Consecutively calling StringBuffer.append with String literals

rule.message: String.indexOf(char) is faster than String.indexOf(String)
rule.name: UseIndexOfChar
rule.description: Use String.indexOf(char) when checking for the index of a single character; it's faster.

rule.message: String.trim().length() ==0 is an inefficient way to validate an empty String
rule.name: InefficientEmptyStringCheck
rule.description: String.trim().length() is an inefficient way to check if a String is really empty, as it creates a new String object just to check its size. Looping through a string, checking Character.isWhitespace() on each character and returning false if a non-whitespace character is found is preferable

rule.message: StringBuffer constructor is initialized with size {0}, but has at least {1} characters appended
rule.name: InsufficientStringBufferDeclaration
rule.description: Failing to pre-size a StringBuffer properly could cause it to re-size many times during runtime. This rule checks the characters that are actually passed into StringBuffer.append(), but represents a best guess "worst case" scenario. An empty StringBuffer constructor initializes the object to 16 characters. This default is assumed if the length of the constructor can not be determined.

rule.message: No need to call String.valueOf to append to a string
rule.name: UselessStringValueOf
rule.description: Use valueOf() argument directly.

rule.message: High amount of different objects as members denotes a high coupling
rule.name: CouplingBetweenObjects
rule.description: Rule counts unique attributes, local variables and return types within an object. An amount higher than specified threshold can indicate a high degree of coupling.

rule.message: A high number of imports can indicate a high degree of coupling within an object.
rule.name: ExcessiveImports
rule.description: A high number of imports can indicate a high degree of coupling within an object. Rule counts the number of unique imports and reports a violation if the count is above the user defined threshold.

rule.message: Avoid using implementation types like ''{0}''; use the interface instead
rule.name: LooseCoupling
rule.description: Avoid using implementation types (i.e., HashSet); use the interface (i.e, Set) instead

rule.message: Avoid really long methods.
rule.name: ExcessiveMethodLength
rule.description: Violations of this rule usually indicate that the method is doing too much. Try to reduce the method size by creating helper methods and removing any copy/pasted code.

rule.message: Avoid really long parameter lists.
rule.name: ExcessiveParameterList
rule.description: Long parameter lists can indicate that a new object should be created to wrap the numerous parameters. Basically, try to group the parameters together.

rule.message: Avoid really long classes.
rule.name: ExcessiveClassLength
rule.description: Long Class files are indications that the class may be trying to do too much. Try to break it down, and reduce the size to something manageable.

rule.message: The {0} ''{1}'' has a Cyclomatic Complexity of {2}.
rule.name: CyclomaticComplexity
rule.description: Complexity is determined by the number of decision points in a method plus one for the method entry. The decision points are 'if', 'while', 'for', and 'case labels'. Generally, 1-4 is low complexity, 5-7 indicates moderate complexity, 8-10 is high complexity, and 11+ is very high complexity.

rule.message: This class has a bunch of public methods and attributes
rule.name: ExcessivePublicCount
rule.description: A large number of public methods and attributes declared in a class can indicate the class may need to be broken up as increased effort will be required to thoroughly test it.

rule.message: Too many fields
rule.name: TooManyFields
rule.description: Classes that have too many fields could be redesigned to have fewer fields, possibly through some nested object grouping of some of the information. For example, a class with city/state/zip fields could instead have one Address field.

rule.message: Assigning an Object to null is a code smell. Consider refactoring.
rule.name: NullAssignment
rule.description: Assigning a "null" to a variable (outside of its declaration) is usually bad form. Some times, the assignment is an indication that the programmer doesn't completely understand what is going on in the code. NOTE: This sort of assignment may in rare cases be useful to encourage garbage collection. If that's what you're using it for, by all means, disregard this rule :-)

rule.message: Avoid assignments in operands
rule.name: AssignmentInOperand
rule.description: Avoid assignments in operands; this can make code more complicated and harder to read.

rule.message: Avoid importing anything from the 'sun.*' packages
rule.name: DontImportSun
rule.description: Avoid importing anything from the 'sun.*' packages. These packages are not portable and are likely to change.
rule.example: import sun.misc.foo; public class Foo {}

rule.message: Suspicious decimal characters following octal escape in string literal
rule.name: SuspiciousOctalEscape
rule.description:
A suspicious octal escape sequence was found inside a String literal. The Java language specification (section 3.10.6) says an octal escape sequence inside a literal String shall consist of a backslash followed by:
OctalDigit | OctalDigit OctalDigit | ZeroToThree OctalDigit OctalDigit
Any octal escape sequence followed by non-octal digits can be confusing, e.g. "\038" is interpreted as the octal escape sequence "\03" followed by the literal character "8".

rule.message: This statement may have some unnecessary parentheses
rule.name: UnnecessaryParentheses
rule.description: Sometimes expressions are wrapped in unnecessary parentheses, making them look like a function call.

rule.message: Perhaps ''{0}'' could be replaced by a local variable.
rule.name: SingularField
rule.description: This field is used in only one method and the first usage is assigning a value to the field. This probably means that the field can be changed to a local variable.

rule.message: Use explicit scoping instead of the default package private level
rule.name: DefaultPackage
rule.description: Use explicit scoping instead of the default package private level

rule.message: Use bitwise inversion to invert boolean values
rule.name: BooleanInversion
rule.description: Use bitwise inversion to invert boolean values - it's the fastest way to do this. See http://www.javaspecialists.co.za/archive/newsletter.do?issue=042&locale=en_US for specific details

rule.message: IHG Naming Conventions - Class and Package names should not have underscores.
rule.name: NoUnderscoresInPackageAndClass
rule.description: The naming conventions that need to be followed.
